title: 103_hr365
content: The Act is titled the "Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993" and includes a congressional finding and declaration of policy. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 aims to address marketing conditions detrimental to small businesses in the livestock and meat food products industry, hindering a free and competitive environment necessary for business health and efficiency. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 aims to assist and protect small businesses by correcting and preventing harmful conditions in the livestock and meat food products industry. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 aims to assist and protect small businesses in the livestock and meat food products industry. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 defines key terms such as "Administrator," "State," "commerce," and "activity affecting commerce." The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 defines key terms such as "person" and "packer" in relation to commerce and business activities. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 defines key terms related to commerce and business activities, including the definition of a "small business meatpacking concern" as a packer with less than a 5% share of the national market. The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 defines key terms related to commerce and business activities, including the definitions of "slaughter," "process," "carcass," "meat food products," and "livestock." The Small Business Preservation and Protection Act of 1993 defines key terms related to commerce and business activities, including the definitions of "livestock," "classification," "livestock futures contract," "retail," and "future livestock transaction." Margin accounts are also referred to as leverage accounts, options, privileges, bids, offers, puts, calls, and guaranties. Prohibited activities in margin accounts. Sec. 4 prohibits certain activities by packers to protect small business meatpacking concerns, including not owning retail meat outlets and limiting slaughter percentages based on national totals. No packer shall engage in any unreasonable use of economic power or discriminate in price between purchasers of meat food products in the US to impair the marketing ability of small business meatpacking concerns. Packer's annual slaughter total shall not exceed 25% of the larger of the last two annual national slaughter totals for the appropriate classification. The packer is prohibited from engaging in unfair practices that harm small businesses in the meatpacking industry. Officers of packers required to file annual reports under the Packers and Stockyards Act are forbidden from participating in future livestock transactions. The packer, subject to annual reporting under the Packers and Stockyards Act, is restricted from participating in livestock futures contracts unless for bona fide hedge transactions. Enforcement authority lies with the Administrator to ensure compliance through complaints filed with relevant US departments or agencies for investigation. Any person or packer found guilty of violating the section will face a fine of up to $500,000 per offense. Each day of violation is considered a separate offense. Small business meatpacking concerns can sue for damages exceeding $10,000. Small business meatpacking concerns can sue in any district court in the United States for threefold damages, including attorney's fees, for activities forbidden by this section. The Act includes provisions for its validity, enforcement of Antitrust Acts, and the effective date of January 1st after enactment.
